description:
Psight refers to a collective of psychics founded by the gifted Clairvoyant known as The Seer. With the aid of a powerful Telepath (Psi-Guardian) she sought out others of various talents to swell their ranks. She organized them in preparation for a war she foresaw hundreds of years into the future. The Psight competed with each other to gain strength and to teach the future generations to use their abilities. This competition became known as Psight, after the order itself.

In Psight, each player takes on the role of a psychic within the order of Psight. The goal is to defeat your opponents using your various Powers, Memories, and Abilities. If you gain Dominance over a Domain, your road to victory may become easier, as your opponents will no longer be able to use any additional Powers, Memories, or Abilities from your Domain. However, plan your actions carefully, because one wrong move could easily spell defeat. With a well-planned strategy and a little luck, you can be the last psychic standing and claim victory!

Psight is a strategy card game designed for 2-4 players. The objective is to out think your opponent and be the last player with cards in your hand. It plays similar to many CCG's without the expense of constantly buying booster packs or individual cards. We strongly disbelieve in the pay-to-win gaming model so everything you need to play with up to 3 other friends or family members is included in the game!

Psight is also a color-blind gamer friendly game with the use of Domain names and symbols on every card in the game.

This    is    it.    This    is    where    the    weathered    parchment    pinpointed    the    Temple    of    the Feathered    Serpent, lost    since    the    conquistadors    who    had    drawn    the    map    disappeared over    500    years    ago.

Pushing    aside    the    great    cycad    fronds    from    the    clearing    you    see    the    ancient    pyramid     before    you.    The    entrance,    you    know,    is    at    the    top.

Climbing,    you    hear    those    sounds    coming    from    the    jungle    behind    you    again.    Something has    been    tracking    you,    waiting    for    an    easy    meal.    It    doesn’t    matter.    The    treasures    of    the Incas    lie    within    this ziggurat and    an    entire    jamboree of    ravenous jaguars    couldn’t    turn you    away    now.

Pushing    aside    the    stone    door    at    the    top,    you    begin    to    descend    the    slick    stone    steps.    What    could    go    wrong    now    that    you’re    so    close?

Temple of the Feathered Serpent (TotFS) is a tile laying game where you you are trying to navigate the ever changing maze to escape an ancient temple.  Watch out for the deadly jaguars and snakes.  The monkeys might sneak up and steal your hard won treasures.

Hey Look!  We have a microbadge:

Fantastic and addictive game. 1-4 players. Normal game mode, map mode, and challenge mode.

Objective: Defeat gold dragon and conquer the magic land with holy runes.

Challenge mode: No map needed. Each player is level 4, and equips 6 runes and 6 scrolls randomly.

Brief Game Rules:
Beginning: each player chooses role card and its side (light or dark), and takes 1 rune and 1 scroll randomly. Next, put the pawn on the battle map (Wasteland-Start Cell) and is Level 1

Process: the active player rolls a dice and moves on the battle map from start cell to Boss cell to fight the boss. When passing Boss cell, the player may choose to challenge the boss or return to the Start cell. When winning the challenge, the player goes to the next map and upgrade one Level.

Battle with monster: player starts first. The player may choose to use ability, rune or scroll in each turn. Ability can only be used once each battle and may be played anytime; only 1 rune can be played in each turn, and tap the rune after its effect (taped rune cannot be used in the same battle unless returned to hand); only 1 scroll can be played in each turn, and remove the scroll from game after its effect. The monster attacks secondly. Choose a monster attack card each turn to activate monster action.

Battle with player: opposing side players can attack each other when their pawns placed in the same cell. Any player can challenge another player when the pawn placed in the Battle Field Cell. The attacker plays first. Each player may use ability, rune and scroll to attack the opponent.

Team with player: same side players can make team when their pawns placed in the same cell. When they attack monster as a team, monster uses the different monster attack card to each team member. When they are attacked by opposing side player, their team status is broken, and the opponent may choose to attack each team member separately.

Cool Factors:

    Normal game mode, map mode, and challenge mode
    Strategic battle with abilities, runes, and scrolls
    Dark and Light camp, Team mode, and Battle Arena

Description:
Business Empire is designed based on economic, financial and management concept in real business world. It demonstrates how to accumulate wealth and develop wealth quotient.

Brief rules:

There are 3 phases in a player’s turn: the beginning phase, the operation phase and the ending phase.
1) The beginning phase: The active player can draw 1 card from top of the library. Then the player generates revenue and pays interest.
2) The operation phase: The active player can build assets; sell assets; borrow liability; refund liability; place deposit; use deposit, operation card and disaster card.
3) The ending phase: If the player has more than 8 cards in hand, the player should choose to discard extra cards.

Cool Factors:

    Simulation to real business world
    Disclose the secret to accumulate wealth
    Easy to start and highly strategic

"Over the Hump Airlift Campaign 1942-1945" is a simulation of the airlift to China in World War II.  The simulation includes 58 pages of rules and procedures, scenarios, counter sheets, and map sections.

There are 16 scenarios beginning with an introductory basic scenario involving one China National Aviation Corporation DC-3 type aircraft flying a pioneering path-finding flight from Assam, India across the Himalayas to Kunming, China.  The second scenario brings in the US Army Air Force using C-47 type aircraft in flying fuel to China for Doolittle's Raiders that they would have used to fly from China to India after the Raid on Tokyo in early 1942.  Scenarios continue chronologically capturing highlights of the airlift campaign and introducing in succession:  C-87, C-46, C-109, and finally C-54 type aircraft.  The final scenario provides for as many as 500 aircraft in a one day maximum effort that occurred on August 1st, 1945 when the Air Transport Command India-China Division made over 1,000 sorties and delivered more than 5,000 tons of cargo to China in a single 24-hour period.  Scenarios provide historical average daily tonnage for comparison of player performance in running airlift operations.

There are four counter sheets on 8-1/2 inch by 11-inch pages with each 1/2-inch by 1/2-inch counter representing a single aircraft with its flight characteristics printed on the counter.  There are eight map pages on 8-1/2 inch by 11-inch pages that can be trimmed to form a map approximately 16 inches by 40 inches with representations of geographic locations, terrain, and altitude bands for flying aircraft counters from India to China and returning for another load.  Various simulation tracks, such as the tonnage delivered, time clock, morale and efficiency, loss rate, and search and rescue level are included on the map sections.  The map also includes loading and turn around boxes at the air fields for tracking aircraft as they land, load or turn around, complete loading or turn-around, are cleared for takeoff, and take off on their next flight.

The simulation is available as a free download and is fully contained in an Adobe Acrobat file that prints out on 58 pages of 8-1/2 by 11-inch paper.  The simulation includes some probability driven aspects of airlift operations, and three or more 10-sided dice can be used for these purposes.  No dice are provided, and players will need to provide dice or other means of generating random numbers.

The simulation is designed for solitaire play.  More than one player can participate by dividing aircraft types among players or dividing operating bases among players.

CFOTD is a light and humorous board game where you play an office worker during the zombie apocalypse.  Maneuver your token through an office building besieged by the armies of the undead to be the first to rescue the CEO and lead him safely to the exit.

Players also control their own zombie that they use to hamper and hinder other players and event cards can help you, hinder you, or give you helpful items to help you win.

Based on zombie B-movie cliches CFOTD brings the campiness of low budget movies into the office.

Card game made as a promotional item for Dettol, a very popular disinfectand in Britain. The game is endorsed by the Child Accident Protection Trust.

The cards consists of pairs of cards. One of the pair warns of a danger and the other gives advice on how to avoid that danger.

Three games are described in the rules. Keeping Me Safe is the main game. The first player places a danger card face up. The next player checks her hand and plays the advice card on top of it (if she holds it). If not the next player looks, and so on. Once a pair has been completed, the next player lays a danger card and the game proceeds until one player has used all their cards. He/she is the winner.

The other two games are more traditional, Snap and Pairs, but both are a little more difficult because the two cards that match are not mirror images which would be more usual in games of Snap or Pairs.

A playful encounter with the painter Albrecht Durer, this memory version. 18 masterpieces of the famous Renaissance artist must be collected after the memory testing, but not in pairs, but in quartets. Each image was divided into four parts, the players will now add back together. First you need to find two matching parts, they are designed to be found later in the game a fitting part, this may be set to. The displayed works are presented in detail in the accompanying booklet.

Simple rules - similar to Trivial Pursuit and some party games - roll the die, move Your game-piece and answer question. If Your answer is correct get the pie of that category. Categories are: Pantomix, What is wanted, Forbidden Words, True or false etc.

Collect piece of pie from each available category to win the game.

Electronically assisted knowledge and reaction game. There are 24 panels on both sides of the display and variety of topics, from animals to ABC and sports equipment. 
One player enters the code number of the card nad the question is answered. Both players simultaneously search for the perfect image and enter its number. Whoever answers correctly gets faster, the point. The display also shows the final score. Who won after an agreed number of tables the most games is the overall winner.

Game with similar mechanism with Trivial Pursuit, the questions relate to the work and training with the Red Cross. 200 question cards with questions in 5 areas of knowledge, including general education.
Object of the game is to collect card from each category to win the game.

From the introduction
"This is a simulation game of US strategic bombing raids from England and Italy on 25 February 1944, the last day of the `Big Week' offensive. Two or three players or teams direct the actions of the opposing air forces as they seek to inflict more damage than they suffer in this attritional contest."

UB Bombers from England and Italy move steadly towards their German targets while the US fighters seek to keep then protected from German fighter attack.  Simple machanics mean the game is easy to learn, but the differing ranges of the fighters and speed of the bombers mean planning ahead is required.  Not knowing when the Germans may attack and cause the fighters to drop their fuel tanks, and so have to return home make this harder than it sounds.

From the introduction -

"This is a simple grand tactical simulation game of the interception of an escorted formation of multiengine daylight bombers during World War Two. Two players or teams direct the actions of the escorting and intercepting fighters as they seek to inflict losses on the opposing aircraft while minimising their own losses. In team play, each player controls one or more specific fighter units, depending on the number of players and the amount of time available."

The counters come in four different sizes, with each larger size corresponding to the next higher altitude band (hence giving an intuitive representation of height, since higher units appear closer and so larger from an overhead perspective).

One of the games in Philip Sabin's book "Simulating War", with counters and map downloadable from his website.

This game has now been published in a deluxe edition by Victory Point games, with full colour components and added historical scenarios.

In Pyramidion, each player plays an Egyptian foreman in charge of a resource supply for the gigantic construction site of the Cheops pyramid. On your turn, you activate sites and play cards in order to gain the biggest influence on these sites. Each foreman will use his contacts among merchants, negotiators and torturers (!) to supply boats located in major cities of Egypt. These boats will set sail in the direction of Giza only when full capacity is reached with the resources they require. The foreman who most effectively furnishes the construction site – the one who first obtains ten victory points – will be rewarded by the Pharaoh himself.

Pyramidion is both a strategic and tactical game, with some luck involved and a lot of player interaction. Are you going to thwart others – or focus on your own success?

Welcome to the world of Diggin Deep: World’s Game, brought to you by Diggin Deep Sports.  With this game, you should be able to re-create a match of soccer complete with all the decisions that the coach would make.  You decide who to dress and who to scratch.  You decide who to start and who to save as a substitute.  You name the starting keeper.  There are also plenty of ‘in game’ decisions to make.  Do I take a shot from the scoring zone, or try to penetrate for a better scoring chance.  If the game is tied late in the second half, do I play conservative, or do I play aggressive and go for the win?  My star midfielder just collapsed due to heat exhaustion.  How do I replace his offense?  How do I replace his defense?  Once you have a solid understanding of the cards, charts, and gameplay, you should be able to play a full regulation match in about thirty minutes.
     
The game is played using three ten sided dice and player cards that represent their abilities on the pitch.  Some players can actually 'dig deep' in certain game situations to tilt the scales in their favor.  It's all here as you attempt to bring glory to your squad.

Sushi Tower is a Japanese toy-style game where players take turns stacking sushi plates on a revolving platform.  As the stack of plates grows ever taller, the tower becomes more and more unstable.  When the tower falls during a player's turn, they must pay for all the plates in the tower.

The game includes three plates of three different colors.  White plates are worth 100 yen and are the most stable plate.  Pink plates are worith 200 yen and have bottom that cause the pink plates to lean a bit.  Blue plates are worth 300 yen and have an off-center bottom, which causes the blue plates to be the most unstable.

The last person with money wins the game!

This is a trivia game about Finland's capital city Helsinki. There are 8 categories of questions: Restaurants & Nightlife, Culture & Sports, History, Streets & Places, Buildings & Statues, Companies & Institutions, Outside Helsinki and Infrastructure & Nature.

Every player chooses a different starting place/category from where they will start to slowly travel towards the spot "Under the clock". You can choose one of the eight categories and that means that you have one more question from the chosen category than other categories, and the starting places are otherwise asymmetric too; for example, a player who's more knowledgeable in the restaurant scene might want to take the route through Eira, while someone who's used to moving about outside of the actual city centre might want to start in the district of Sörnäinen.

All question cards have a hard and an easy question. If you choose the hard question and get it right then you get to the next place and you can go on. If you choose the easy question and get it right then you get to the next place, but your turn is over. If your answer is not right, you won't get forward at all, so the only way to progress in the game is to know (or guess) the trivia correctly.

Winner is the first player to get "Under the Clock". "Nähdään kellon alla" (or, in it's full form, "Nähdään Stockan kellon alla") is a Helsinki saying and means "See you under the [Stockmann] clock". The clock in question is the overhanging clock by the main entrance of the Stockmann department store, which has been a city landmark and a well-known meeting point in Helsinki since 1965. Thematically, the players have agreed to meet each other "Under the clock" and the first one to arrive made it in time, while the others will be late.

The game is fully Finnish/Swedish bilingual on purpose, down to every single detail; this is stressed out in the rules, to emphasize Helsinki as a bilingual city with both of the official languages of Finland, Finnish and Swedish.

A version of the game set in Tampere, the second biggest city of Finland was published in 2017: NÃ¤hdÃ¤Ã¤n Kosken Rannassa, and one set in Turku, the former capital and now the third biggest city of Finland, in 2019; NÃ¤hdÃ¤Ã¤n TÃ¤l Pual Jokke.

Blockers! The Card Game recreates the Blockers! board game with similar gameplay but new goals. Instead of a 9x9 grid, players will now play onto a 4x4 grid, with 16 victory cards comprising the spaces of that grid. Frame cards surround this grid to label the rows (A-D), columns (1-4) and 2x2 regions (labeled with card suits).

On a turn, a player plays a "hand" card that specifies a row, column or 2x2 region and claims one victory card in the appropriate location. (Alternatively, a player can use a kicker card as a joker.) Each time you claim a victory card after the first one, the card must match the color or shape on the victory card that you claimed the previous turn. Once all players pass, the round ends and empty spaces on the board are refilled with victory cards. When the victory card deck is exhausted, the game ends and the player with the most victory cards wins.

Reimplements:

    Blockers!

Schafköpfchen is an easy variation of Schafkopf, a trick-taking game popular in Austria and Bavaria. In each of the four colors of cards in the deck are six cards numbered 1-6; the deck also contains gray cards numbered 7-15, which are always trump. An additional trump color is determined each round by die roll.

Each round, a player starts with eight cards in hand. The starting player plays a card, and the others have to follow the suit, if possible. The player with the higest card of the played color or a trump gets the trick. After eight tricks, players look at the cards they collected. Some of the cards show flowers, and the player with the most flowers scores 1 point.

The first player to collect 3 points wins.

Objective: be the first moving your 3 meeples into target zone
 - moving by turns -
throw the die and move according rolled number;
you need a '6' to step out and a '6' for an additional move;
target zone can be reached passing the turntable only;
if a meeple blocks/sits on a 'D' space turntable may be moved;
you may jump over other meeples, but your own one blocks you.
remarks:
published before/during WWII

A boardgame that is based on the real Operation Storm, from 1995, when the Croatian army liberated Knin from the Serbian-Chetnik aggressor. This game is shows the heroic Operation Storm in a educational way so that the heroic acts of Croatian soldiers may never be forgotten.

The game is meant for 4 players, and each one has its figure and throws the dice. Depending on the dice result, player takes over the fields on the board, and the start position is in the area of Croatian Kostajnica. All along the line where Croatian army passed are drawn tanks aswell as Croatian soldiers and Serbian-Chetnik occupators. The winner is the first one that liberates the city of Knin. There is a pamphlet with real-life historical facts about Operation Storm.

By this educational and fun system the goal of this boardgame is to commemorate the heroism of the Croatian Armed Forces during the Operation Storm, and may it never be forgotten.

This is a Family game with a mix of questions about Norwegian geography, history and culture.
Every Player are to visit 16 random towns/villages, and have to plan their own route and try to be the first to return to their "home town".
You move around by throwing dice, and there are little twists like ferry that you either have to have a ticket for or throw a 1 or 5 on the dice to pass. and you can also get plane-tickets which makes it easier to get from one end to the other quick if you are lucky. 
in most games getting a 6 on the dice is good, but here you have to answer a trivia question, and if you manage to answer the question-card tells you how many places you can move. 
if you're lucky(?) you can go through the whole game without having to answer an actual trivia question.

it's a good game for the whole family, but I would recommend from ages 10 and up. it's a better game if players are on more equal terms.

In 1347, The Black Death ravages Europe. The ruler of your land has just succumbed to the plague, and now you, the princes of the land, compete against one another in a struggle to replace him. To do this you travel around the land to gather loyal supporters from among the various classes of the middle ages. Each day you visit a different town, each containing different kinds of buildings and each providing different kinds of benefits. When entering a building belonging to a given class, you recruit followers from that class. Once in a while, you also take a chance on recruiting some of the strangers lurking in the streets. There are a few rats in those streets, too, but a rat or two won't kill you, right?

Rattus Cartus, a card game based on the Rattus board game, includes twelve different buildings with players using all or only some of them each game to provide a wide variety of play. Are you going to play it safe, or will you run the risk of perishing from the effects of the plague?

At the turn of the 16th century in Japan both the Emperor and the tycoon lost control of the country – the time when pushy and ambitious daimyos to subdue islands, the time for strong warriors to demonstrate their boldness and great warlords to show their art, the time when cunning secret agents decided a battle of the clans.

In the tactical card game Shinobi: War of Clans players will take on the role of secret agents of the most powerful clans of feudal Japan. The aim of the game is supporting your clan with military advantage; the clan which has the most troops at the end of the game wins.

At the beginning of the game each player gets a clan card which shows what clan the player will belong to and four troop cards from the deck. The area before the player (his table) presents one of Japan’s provinces, so the more players the more provinces. The players take turns clockwise from the starting player. Each player’s turn consists of the following orders: the troop deployment order, the troop movement order and the attacking order. During his turn the player must place a card from his hand on any province except his own one. If by the end of his turn in his province he raised the army (some troops of the same clan) which is stronger (more numerous) than any other army in any other province, the battle is unavoidable. It will be impossible to stop the warlike samurais from attacking but there is an opportunity to direct them to the proper side.  Once there are no more cards in the deck players take a final turn and come in true colors (reveal their secret cards). Clan cards are summed up and the player with the most cards of his clan in all the provinces wins the game.

What’s feudal Japan without ninjas! Without them no game about Japan can be complete. The ninjas’ function is obvious – to shorten the number of warriors from the enemy clans.

From 3 to 5 players can take part in the game. The tactics of the game changes depending on the number of players. You will need careful calculation to win in a five-player game; fans of bluff and "psychological" game will like the game with three participants. The game seems simple at first sight, but believe or not, keeping your clan in secret, guessing which clans your rivals play for and making them to play into your hands is not simple at all.

This game is Game #32 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.  It is a game involving 32 pieces on 32 spaces, for up to 32 players.  Players attempt to coordinate and negotiate in order to work their way to the top of their group, and add other players to their group, by moving their piece (or being part of a group that moves).

At the end of the game, a player's score is where their piece(s) is/are in its stack.

In the mid-sixteenth century England, Queen Elizabeth I rules without an heir. This leaves room for some maneuvering. Powers throughout, including you, believe that a family with great presence, wealth, and nobility might find itself in the right place at the right time.

In Noblemen, you are members of the British aristocracy. You will try to achieve influence and prestige for your family. You will grow your family's estate, earn the queen's favor, bear witness to scandalous behavior, gain influence with the church, bribe royalty, and leverage your political weight during masquerade balls, all in an effort to ensure your family's rightful place in history. After three decades, the player with the most victory points will be declared the winner.

This is a game of several races all going on at the same time. Players race the clock; you will never know exactly how many turns are remaining before the scoring round. Players will race each other – to build cheaper buildings, to be the first to build a folly, to have more prestige and therefore gain a higher noble title, and more. On your turn you can play one scandal card (if you choose) in addition to taking one action from the following possibilities:


     Grow Estate – Play lands from behind your screen
     Build Structure – Buy and play a building on a meadow 
     Bribe Royalty – Buy bribe tickets you can redeem later
     Collect Taxes – Get money
     Acquire Lands – Get more land from the bag of random lands
     Donate to the Church – Redeem lands for victory points
     Leisure Time – Get one victory point


On most of your turns, you will build your estate by playing land tiles or building structures. There are three commodities to concentrate on: lands, wealth, and prestige. Each commodity will help on your path to victory. It is for you to decide each turn which is the most needed for you to win the game.

From the box front: A New Classic Game of Beauty and Skill As Interesting as Chess, Easy as Checkers. A Two Player Game Enjoyed by All Ages.

Players take turns adding tiles to the board, extending a line from a starting space marked on the board. The winner is the first player to reach the opponent's starting space.

Part of the Genus edition of the TRIVIAL PURSUIT series this time questions are about Austria.

The game contains questions in the six familiar categories: Geography, Entertainment, History, Art & Literature, Science & Nature, Sports & Leisure.

Quiz game with motion/dice mechanism on the basis of Trivial Pursuit, general knowledge questions plus questions on first aid and Red Cross matters.

Roll the dice, move You pawn and draw a card. Answer the question from the category You are standing and if it is correct take the card.
Collect cards from each category for win the game.

Objective: be the first collecting one card of each catagory(5): mammalian, birds, insects, fruits, vegetables
 - acting simultaneously -
active player draws card asking first question/hint; player who answers first gets the card; if first hint does not work
second hint (up to five) is given...
 easier version: first player collecting 5 cards wins
remarks:
seems to be an enlarged remake of Wunder der Natur

Objectice: get most chips by answering questions correctly
 - acting simultaneously -
all players make up their decisions, which of 3 answers should
be the correct one placing a bet (chip)
correct answer doubles the bet, incorrect one => lose your chip;
game ends if a player gets rid of chips.
'expert' variant: no multiple choice, give correct answer
remarks:
seems to be an expended remake of RÃ¤tsel, Rekorde, Sensationen

Objective: be the first getting 7 golden coins
- acting by turn -
there are 28 slides upside down (6 different images) + 6 round tasks slides (visible images);
if you put the 'Pippi' pawn upon one of these task slides and aks 'how often' => next player may open the bet; the following one may increase or pass until no one increases anymore.
if the player turns over appropiate number: + 2 coins
wrong: other players get 1 coin each.

Children's card game that calls for bluffing to win. 44 cards provided: 6 of each Ingredient card, 6 Pepper cards, 6 Broomstick cards and 2 reminder cards of the order that must be followed when announcing Ingredients.

Each player gets a hand of cards and must play them all first to win. The ingedients are;
1. Citrouille (Pumpkin)
2. Crapauds (Frogs)
3. Asticots (Worms
4. Araignees (Spiders
5. Champignons (Mushrooms)

The game mechanic relies on the popular playing card game Cheat. The first player chooses a card and announces "Citrouille" (in a high voice the rules says!). If he does not have such a card, he must choose one anyway and announce it as if it was the correct card. If not challenged, he can discard the card on to the discard pile. If challenged and it is correct or incorrect, the offending player (either the player or the challenger) must draw extra cards as a penalty. Then it is the next player's turn and he must announce "Crapauds" and choose a card, and follow the same rules. The next player announces "Asticots", and so on.

Poivre cards and Balai cards add to the fun. A Poivre (Pepper) card played means that your turn passes to the next player. And if a Balai (Broom) card is played and challenged, the challenger tales all the cards in the discard pile.

The first player to get rid of all their cards, wins.

Children's card game. 36 cards comprising of 30 Cabbage cards (with 1 to 3 cabbages on them), 2 Snail cards and 4 Hedgehog picture cards.

All the cards are shuffled and the first player takes the top card. If it is a Cabbage card, he lays it in front of him. If it is a part of the hedgehog picture, it is placed in the centre of the table. If it is a Snail, the player must return it to the deck of unused cards together with all his Cabbage cards. The pack is then shuffled again. Then the next player draws a card and follows the same instructions.

The game ends when all four parts of the Hedgehog picture have been revealed and the winner is the one with the most cabbages in their possession at that time. (Note: the rules say the most Cabbage cards wins but this must be wrong or, otherwise, having 1, 2 or 3 Cabbages on the cards would be meaningless).

The box is one which extends, that is, the inner sleeve slides down to reveal the character up a tall ladder and watering her cabbages.

Simple trick-taking game for the young (maybe intended to be their first experience of taking tricks). The four Trophy cards are set aside and shuffled and one drawn at random. This nominates the trump suit, be it Crocodiles, Apes, Lions or Elephants.

Thereafter it follows all the normal rules for taking tricks; Must follow suit if you can, may trump if you can't or you may play any card you wish to get rid of.

The winner is the player with the most cards after all the tricks have been played.

With Border Bed, instead of having the bed completely stolen by your partner during night, you will play bed space through series of questions and actions. The most successful player will enjoy more bed space - to the detriment of the other - for the following night.

At the beginning, the bed is equally split on the “bed space” tracker. Then, each player moves one after the other on a simple board using a D6. Depending on where the player ends up, he or she will need to either answer a question or perform an action - on a successful answer, he/she will gain 5 cm on the bed (the other losing an equal amount) and will be allow to play again.
A few squares on the board have extra bonuses/maluses beside the basic question or action.

Questions are taken from a trivial pursuit style deck, with 5 categories: sport/entertainement/musik, general knowledge, day-to-day life, erotism/sexuality, and “personal”. The last one typically consist of question asking you to know something about your partner - favorite dish, name of first pet and more personal things. Actions come from an action card deck. They usually involves some personal things - kissing your partner for more than 10s, doing a massage and so on.

The game ends when one of the player arrives at the last position on the board. The loser - player who is going to have less space on the bed - can still decide to perform a few extra actions to regain a bit of space.

Build up a full meal using recipes from all French Regions by answering trivia questions about French gastronomy. The game comes with a full cookbook of the 264 dishes mentioned in the game.

Questions are the main part of the game - they come from a deck of cards, each card corresponding to one region local dish and containing 4 different questions - e.g., what composes a traditional dish, where the name of specialty comes from and so on.

Each player is randomly assigned a french region at the beginning of the game and tries to build a full menu - first course, main dish, cheese, desert, drink and a speciality - preferably with recipes from the region. First player to have a complete menu win the game.

Every time a player answers correctly a question, he/she will be able to either add it to his/her own menu if the dish (written on the question card) was from the same region and that the menu slot is still empty. Otherwise, a token mechanism still allows the player to eventually fill in its menu slots.

Objective: get as many cards as possible
 - acting simultaneously -
place 8 cards uncovered upon the table;
distribute remainig cards among players, forming a staple;
simultaneously all players uncover their top one;
if there is a matching one in the middle - grasp at it as fast as possible.
Successfully catching a card players have to form a 'loot' staple, on top last obtained card, uncovered! If a player uncovers a matching card during next turns the whole staple can be caught. Game ends after all 8 cards are picked up.

Objective: be the first getting rid of all your cards
 - acting by turn/reacting simultaneously -
all cards are distributed among players; staples are formed & active player unvovers top card:
Person or the ape => each player must shout the correct title simultaneously. Correct - discard your card into the centre of the table; wrong - take all the cards out of the centre;
if the card shows a bag - put your hand as fast as you can into the centre - the very last one has to take all the cards.

"The world of animals" in English
On 32 cards there are 2 questions with three answers each, on the back with information and illustration on the subject. Players receive questions cards, in case of 3 and 4 players also betting cards.

The active player is asked by the quizmaster, if the first answer is right, he is asked the second question. If the answer is again correct, the player receives the card and places it with his betting cards. In case the first answer was wrong the left neighbour of the player can risk an answer and use one of his betting cards. If he answers wrong, he loses he card. When no one has questions cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

St. George's Gauntlet is a "push your luck" dice game. As a knight of the Order of St. George, you must collect gems from a cavern guarded by a gauntlet of dragons. The roll of the dice determines whether you collect gems or get killed by the dragons. Certain rolls will allow you to kill the dragons, if you are willing to take the risk of rolling a special "Dragon Slayer Die". Collecting the last gem in a level of the cavern results in a big bonus, but failure gives your opponents an easier shot! Do you leave the cavern to earn glory, or push forward for greater rewards?

The game can be played two ways: In the Basic Game, all players compete until the sixth  level of the cavern is explored. In the challenging "Video Game" variant, each player begins with a set number of lives and is eliminated when all lives are lost.

The Birth of America series continues with The American Revolution.

In 1775: Rebellion, players take the roles of the American Continental Army and Patriots against the British Army and the Loyalists. Each side tries to control the colonies, provinces and territories. They call on the aid of Native Americans, as well as the German Hessians and French Army in order to successfully birth a revolution or quell the rebellion. The four factions each use their own deck of cards to move their units into positions. Battles are resolved quickly with custom dice. If you can control an entire colony, province or territory you raise a flag. When the game ends with the signing of the Treaty of Paris, the side with the most flag markers is the winner.

1775: Rebellion uses the same basic mechanisms as 1812: The Invasion of Canada, but to a different end result. The game is quicker (being 2-4 player) and the intermingling of units at the beginning of the game allows the action to start immediately. There are a few core rules that changed in order to better portray the goals of the war.

The game also comes with an advanced scenario, "The Siege of Quebec". We recommend this for players comfortable with the basic rules.

Winner of BGG "Golden Geek 2013" Award for "Best Wargame."

A funny and thrilling strategy game for the whole family!

Imagine you're a circus owner and must hire the most talented artist crew to your show! But, the best artists are the most sought after, and, beyond that, you must also wittingly use your money to improve your circus. And of course, don't let the marketing down or you won't gather the crowd to improve your income!
[Taken from the publisher's website.]

--x--x--
The game takes only 4 rounds, during which the players will get income, pick two business partners to work with (which will help them with additional powers), get new artists or possibly send them to the cooperative in a new, ingenious distribution mechanic and then invest on their business. During the investment phase, a player will have the opportunity to hire artists from the cooperative, get improvements for his circus, advertise the new show in town and set up tents for the selling of merchandise.
After every two rounds there'll be a show, in which players will score their circus and then move on to another town (thus, discarding everything but artists and improvements).

After the two shows (that is, 4 rounds), the player with the most points is the winner!

Um divertido e emocionante jogo de estratégia para toda a família!
Imagine que você é dono de um grande circo, e deverá contratar o mais talentoso elenco de artistas para apresentar seu espetáculo! Porém, os melhores artistas são muito disputados, e além disso, você também deverá usar seu dinheiro com sabedoria para melhorar as suas instalações. E claro! Não deixe de fazer as propagandas certas para atrair mais público e aumentar sua renda!
[Retirado do site da fabricante.]

--x--x--
O jogo leva apenas 4 rodadas, durante as quais, os jogadores irão ganhar dinheiro, selecionar 2 parceiros (que lhes ajudarão com poderes adicionais), conseguir novos artistas ou possívelmente enviá-los para a cooperativa em um engenhosa mecânica e então, investir em seus negócios.
Durante a fase de investimento,  um jogador terá a oportunidade de contratar artistas da cooperativa, comprar melhorias, fazer propaganda do novo espetáculo na cidade ou armar barracas para vender mercadorias durante os shows.
A cada duas rodadas terá um espetáculo, durante o qual os jogadores pontuarão e então irão para outra cidade (descartando, assim, tudo exceto artistas e melhorias).
Após dois espetáculos (ou seja, 4 rodadas), quem tiver a maior pontuação será o vencedor!

This is a turn-based strategic world domination game with economic/industrial, resource and military planning components.  It is currently a proposed Kickstarter project.

There are three main layers to WW3.  The first is industrial/economic production.  Control the centers of industry, and you earn their production points.  However, such control can be gained either through economic investment OR military adventurism.  To invade or to invest, that is the question!

The second layer is fuel and resource production.  Fuel helps your armies move faster, and your fleets to move MUCH faster.  But use up all your fuel on movement, and you may not have much left over for battle.  Remember that an army fighting without fuel will be struggling for its very survival.

The final layer to game play is, of course, the military dimension.  The basic version of the game will have two types of military units: armies and fleets.  Unlike in Risk, where ridiculous numbers of armies start crowding the board very quickly, WW3 forces you to make tough choices with limited military forces.  The loss of just one critical army at a key moment could prove lethal; every strategic choice in this game is critical.

Game description from the publisher:

Deep in the jungle of the mysterious Oobydoobies, high atop the Cliff of Frab, your expedition has discovered an incredible treasure that will grant the owner amazing power! But, what's this? No one in your group wants to share the treasure! Use your supplies, your wits, and some ancient magic left by the Oobydoobies to build a path to the top of the Cliff of Frab. Crush, roast, or explode your opponents, and try to claim the treasure before anyone else!

Jungle Ascent is a racing game in which players must build a pathway up the perilous Cliff of Frab with ladders, bridges, and conveyor belts while sending opponents tumbling down with hazards such as Fireballs and Crushers. Action cards such as Speed Juice and Construction will also make players' lives a bit easier during the climb.

The first player to scale to the top of the Cliff of Frab claims its untold treasures and wins the game!

Objective: get rid of most 'Olchi'-chips, evenly distributed
 - acting by turns -
a garbage dump is prepared by placing cards = 'Olchi' items and oil drums (fire supplies for the dragon) vertically into board & box; next to the box 11 digging chips have to be placed.
Active player rolls the coloured die and turns the box in a way, looking at the matching colour (=digger) or oil drum; using the 'Olchi' tongs a card has to be drawn: an 'Olchi' item? => drop one of your chips; an oil drum? remove a digging chip;
if the die showed an oil drum symbol the dragon requires supply: now the player should draw an 'oil drum' card instead...
Game ends if all digging chips are gone; in case that a player dropped all his 'Olchi' chips game ends at once.

Children's motorized action game. Part of a series of games entitled T.H.I.N.G.S. or Totally Hilarious Incredibly Neat Games of Skill. This is a hippopotamus themed game with a pop-a-shot mechanic. The goal is to flip all 8 plastic marbles into the hippos mouth before the time stops. The hippos mouth opens and closes while the player attempts to shoot in all the marbles.

From the box: "Flip the hippo a mouthful of marbles!"

Ages 5 and up for 1 or more players.

Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #14.

Multi-players game for vassals of Oda Nobunaga in Sengoku period of Japan. Oda Nobunaga was most powerful daimyo(feudal lord) in Sengoku period.
"Yuke! Nobunaga Kashindan" means Go! Nobunaga's Vassals.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oda_Nobunaga

Each player control one major vassals in Oda clan.
Standard game can play from three to five players. The game also include rule for one(solitaire) and two players.

Each counter represents a vassal to serve Oda clan. Each vassal have three ability, military, castellation and politic. During in the game, players can recruit vassals to own faction.

Each card represents a mission be ordered from Oda Nobunaga. Each mission has victory points, necessary abilities and penalty of failure.

Elect chief vassal at the beginning of each turn. Then, chief vassal is draw mission cards and he assigns missions to each player. Players can negotiate freely for achieve mission.
Repeat until the mission is exhausted.

Winner is determined by victory points.

The wars with the Grayking have taken their toll. Lassadar's defenses are not as they once were, the Wardens are greatly reduced in number and magic is seemingly drained from the land.

From the South now arises a new threat. Twelve dread barons have formed a pact and pledged to take Lassadar for their own. They have gathered their armies and new allies - the Trulls, hulking brutes that hurl stones like mobile catapults - and have come north to Dalnish, a border city and first line of defense against invasion, to lay siege.

The Tower of Dalnish stands ready to repel the invasion but supplies and soldiers are limited. As the Captain of the Guard, it is your responsibility to hold out long enough for reinforcements to arrive. Rally your men, ready your weapons. They are upon you.....

A solo tower siege game lasting about 20 minutes and is the first game in the 2nd Lassadar game trilogy.

You, and the forces you command, must hold out long enough until Reinforcements arrive (drawn from the Event deck). If you can succeed in this you will drive the Barons and their armies back across the Southern border. If all of your Tower’s battlements are destroyed by Enemy Units or all of your Tower Units are slain or destroyed you lose the game and Lassadar is invaded.

42 cards, divided into Defensive Units, Enemy Units and Events are payed on a 2 section game board. Each Unit has a set of attack and defensive values. Using Action Points units played by the player can be deployed, engaged and repaired.

Unique to this game are Damage Pattern footprints that players must use effectively to combat Enemy Units.

A series of Event cards act as an AI in the game changing game play as the rounds progress. These cards are drawn when sufficient damage is done to the Enemy Units

Dice counters have been provided along with the card files/player board. Players may substitute 8mm dice if they prefer.

1st Place - Best Science Fiction/Fantasy Themed Game - 2012 Solitaire PNP Contest
2st Place - Best Artwork for an Entered Game Category - 2012 Solitaire PNP Contest
Grand Prize - 2012 Solitaire PNP Contest

Simple Game for boys and girls 8-12. Object of the game is to get from your Pirate Ship into the cove with as much treasure as you can while avoiding bad things that could happen to you. Roll and move type game, turn over hidden pieces of treasure or turn over skull and crossbones and find nothing.
